The Cabinet met at short notice, as a matterof urgency, to consider the latest developmentsPreviousReference: of the situation in Egypt. Besides telegramCabinet 35(26), Con- No. 195, of June Snd, to Lord Lloyd, forwardingelusion 1.) ...the text of the draft message to be sent by lord lloyd to Zaghloul Pasha, approved by the cabinet at their previous Meeting, they had before themLord Lloyd's telegram No. 263, of June Snd,forwarding his draft of the declaration to .Zaghloul, which had crossed Sir Austen ChamberlairisNo. 195, together with Lord Lloyd's No, 368 ofJune 3rd, making certain comments on No. 195.Included among the documents also was a telegram.from Lord Lloyd, No. 269, which had arrived afterthe Cabinet had been summoned but before it met,notifying that Zaghloul had now abandoned his idea of becoming Prime Minister and wished AdlyPasha to form a Cabinet. Sir Austen ChambBrlainhanded round a draft telegram to Lord Lloyd as abasis for discussion.The Cabinet agreed That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs should reply to telegram No. 269 to the effectthat His Majesty's Government was prepared to revert to the proposalunder which Adly Pasha should forma Government, but that if ZaghloulPasha should change his mind again -and should wish to become PrimeMinister, Lord Lloyd should forward to him the Note approved at thelast Meeting of the Cabinet; amended as explained in the telegramattached as an Appendix to this conclusion.itehall Gardens, S.VM, . . .June 3, 1926. APPENDIX.EGYPT.Telegram from Foreign Office to Lord Lloyd (Cairo), dated june 3rd. 1926, 6 p.m.No. 202.Urgent.Your telegram No. 269 of June 3rd.If Zaghloul adheres to this decision not to seek Prime Ministership, you will we presume pursuepolicy foreshadowed in your earlier conversations with Adly, encourage him to form ministry and to co-operate with you in pursuit of common Interests ofEgypt and ourselves.If Zaghloul again changes his mind, you willhave to announce the decision of His Majesty's -Government to him.His Majesty's Government have carefully con-sidered observations contained In your telegram No. -268of June 3rd. They have decided that our draft Is a shorter and clearer presentation of our case. Theyapprove however inclusion of reference to officials and agreements with foreign powers.There remains the vital question whether the termsof our draft are such as to permit Zaghloul now toproffer dishonestly and with intention of later break-ing his promises the assurances which he refused togive in his conversation wi th you.This was not our intention. We recited what had actually happened and gave our decision on the situ-ation thus created. Last hour assurances given under pressure would be valueless and cannot be accepted.Our feeling is that his attitude in conversationwith you was decisive as to his real intentions.To make this clear insert in our draft contained inmy telegram No. 195- after the words "in the lightof the events of your last administration" thefollowing (begins) I am bound to make it plain thatthe oonviction left upon my mind by our conversationwas such that I cannot advise His Majesty^ Governmentto reopen the discussion (ends).Opening words of next paragraph should read"1 find it necessary to add".
